questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is formed in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: D.

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, which is the innermost layer of the abdominal wall.
  • It is located above and medial to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament.
  • The deep inguinal ring is an important anatomical landmark in the inguinal region and serves as the starting point of the inguinal canal.

Incorrect options:

Option A. External oblique aponeurosis: The external oblique aponeurosis contributes to the formation of the superficial inguinal ring, which is a separate structure from the deep inguinal ring.

Option B. Internal oblique aponeurosis: The internal oblique aponeurosis also contributes to the formation of the superficial inguinal ring, not the deep inguinal ring.

Option C. Transversus abdominis: The transversus abdominis muscle lies deep to the internal oblique muscle and its aponeurosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the deep inguinal ring.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a fever and massive splenomegaly. The spleen was 15 cm on palpation and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Phrenicocolic ligament:

  • The phrenicocolic ligament is a peritoneal fold that extends from the left colic flexure to the diaphragm, supporting the spleen inferiorly. It acts as a shelf that prevents the spleen from descending vertically into the left lower quadrant, limiting downward displacement in conditions like massive splenomegaly.

Lienorenal ligament (option A): Also called the splenorenal ligament, it connects the spleen to the left kidney and contains the splenic vessels and tail of the pancreas. It provides posterior support but does not prevent downward descent of the spleen.

Gastrosplenic ligament (option B): This ligament connects the stomach to the spleen and contains the short gastric arteries and left gastroepiploic artery. It mainly stabilizes the spleen anteromedially but does not prevent downward movement.

Lienophrenic ligament (option D): Also called the splenophrenic ligament, it attaches the spleen to the diaphragm and provides superior support. It prevents upward displacement, not downward movement.

questions.text: Where are the Ito cells in the liver located?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Space of disse

Explanation:

  • Ito cells, or hepatic stellate cells, reside in the space of Disse within the liver, situated between sinusoidal endothelial cells and hepatocytes in liver lobules. This space holds extracellular matrix components, growth factors, and signaling molecules, creating a crucial microenvironment. Ito cells play a vital role in liver function and pathology.

Hepatic stellate cells (or Ito cells):

  • Located in the space of Disse, between hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells in the liver.
  • In the healthy liver, these cells store vitamin A in lipid droplets.
  • In response to injury, they activate and contribute to fibrosis by releasing TGFβ.

 

Space of Moll (Option B): The space of Moll is a small space located between the posterior surface of the cornea and the anterior surface of the iris. It is not related to the location of Ito cells in the liver.

Sinusoids (Option C): While Ito cells are located in close proximity to the sinusoids, they are specifically found within the space of Disse, which is a distinct anatomical space within the liver

Bile canaliculi (Option D): Bile canaliculi are tiny channels between adjacent hepatocytes that transport bile towards the bile ducts. Ito cells are not located within the bile canaliculi.

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiated the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland?

choices.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini
Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absence of striated duct

Explanation:

  • One key difference between the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland is the absence of striated ducts in the pancreas. Striated ducts, found in glands like the parotid, modify secretions with characteristic basal infoldings. In contrast, the pancreas relies on intercalated ducts, lacking these basal infoldings, to transport enzymes from acinar cells to the main duct.

 

HISTOLOGY OF PANCREAS:

  • The pancreas consists of exocrine and endocrine glands.
  • The exocrine portion, made up of acini, secretes digestive enzymes and resembles a serous salivary gland.
  • The endocrine portion, represented by the Islets of Langerhans, produces hormones like insulin and glucagon to regulate blood glucose levels.

 

Histology of Pancreas. Beta cells (2) of the pancreatic islet (4) Serous acini (1) of the pancreas are stained with H and E. Centroacinar cells (3) can be seen in the serous acini

 

Basal lamina lining the serous acini (Option B): Both the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland have a basal lamina lining the serous acini. The basal lamina provides structural support to the acinar cells.

Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip (Option C): Both the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland can have serous acini with acidophilic (eosinophilic) cytoplasmic granules at their apical (or luminal) ends.

Presence of apical acinar villi (Option D): Neither the exocrine pancreas nor the parotid gland have apical acinar villi.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy underwent splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed bleeding while separating the spleen from the stomach. Which vessel is most likely implicated in this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Short gastric vessels

 

Explanation:

  • The short gastric vessels arise from the splenic artery and drain into the splenic vein.
  • These vessels run within the gastrosplenic ligament, connecting the fundus of the stomach to the spleen.
  • During splenectomy, when the spleen is being separated from the stomach, these vessels must be ligated to prevent bleeding.
  • Since the short gastric arteries lack a collateral blood supply, their injury can lead to fundal ischemia.

Blood Supply of the Stomach and Its Surgical Relevance

Arterial Supply

Origin

Left gastric artery

Branch of the celiac trunk, supplies the lesser curvature

Right gastric artery

Branch of the proper hepatic artery, supplies the lesser curvature

Short gastric arteries

Branches of the splenic artery, supply the fundus

Right gastroepiploic artery

Branch of the gastroduodenal artery, supplies the greater curvature

Left gastroepiploic artery

Branch of the splenic artery, supplies the greater curvature

Left gastric vessels (Option A): Incorrect because these supply the lesser curvature of the stomach and are not directly involved in splenic separation.

Gastroepiploic vessels (Option C): Incorrect because these supply the greater curvature and are located in the gastrocolic ligament, away from the spleen.

Splenic vessels (Option D): Incorrect because these are major vessels supplying the spleen itself, but they do not cause significant bleeding when separating the spleen from the stomach.

questions.text: Ligation of common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in:

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

Explanation:

The common hepatic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk and gives rise to:

  • Proper hepatic artery → Right gastric artery
  • Gastroduodenal artery → Right gastroepiploic artery

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply to:

  • Right gastric artery (supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach)
  • Right gastroepiploic artery (supplies the greater curvature of the stomach)

 

Right gastric and left gastric artery (option B): The left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk, so it will still receive blood despite common hepatic artery ligation.

Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels (option C): The right gastroepiploic artery comes from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery) and will be affected. Short gastric arteries, however, arise from the splenic artery, which remains intact.

Right gastric and short gastric vessels (option D): The right gastric artery is affected. The short gastric vessels come from the splenic artery and remain unaffected.

questions.text: A tumor of the uncinate process of the pancreas affects which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Superior mesenteric artery

Explanation:

  • The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small, hook-like projection from the head of the pancreas that extends posteriorly and inferiorly, wrapping around the superior mesenteric vessels (SMA and SMV).
  • A tumor in this region is likely to compress or invade the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which supplies blood to the midgut (small intestine and proximal colon).

 

Relationship of the Pancreas, Veins, and Aorta in Nutcracker Syndrome

Nutcracker Syndrome:

  • A condition caused by compression of the left renal vein leading to the left renal vein hypertension.
  • Highlights the anatomical relationship between the pancreas, veins, and aorta.

Anatomical Features

Description

Left Renal Vein

Originates from the hilum of the left kidney.

Travels behind the pancreas and splenic vein.

Crosses the abdominal aorta anteriorly below the superior mesenteric artery.

Nutcracker Analogy

The left renal vein is compressed between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery, resembling a nutcracker.

Symptoms

Can lead to left renal vein hypertension.

Symptoms include hematuria and varicocele, especially in children.

Pancreas' Role in Nutcracker Syndrome:

  • Positioned directly in front of the compression site, anterior to the SMA.
  • Proximity to vascular structures suggests the potential to worsen the condition.
  • The uncinate process being close to the superior mesenteric artery and vein further emphasises the pancreas's proximity to major vessels.

Portal vein (option B): Formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and splenic vein, located posterior to the neck of the pancreas. The uncinate process is more inferior, so it typically does not directly compress the portal vein.

Common hepatic artery (option C): Arises from the celiac trunk and gives rise to the proper hepatic artery and gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the pancreas and is not typically affected by tumors of the uncinate process.

Inferior mesenteric artery (option D): Arises from the abdominal aorta at a lower level, supplying the hindgut (distal colon and rectum). It is too distant from the uncinate process to be affected.

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is a defect in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fascia transversalis

Explanation:

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

Inguinal canal:

Structure

Description

Parietal peritoneum

Most posterior structure.

Transversalis fascia

Has a defect called the deep inguinal ring, through which the testes and spermatic cord pass. Site for indirect inguinal hernias. Anterior to parietal peritoneum. Forms the posterior in the whole extent.

Lateral umbilical fold

Formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

Median umbilical ligament

Remnant of the urachus (from the allantois).

Medial umbilical ligament

Remnant of the obliterated umbilical artery.

Pyramidalis muscle

Small muscle attaching to the pubic bone. Rectus abdominis lies above it. Covered by the rectus sheath and supplied by the subcostal nerve (T12).

Rectus abdominis muscle

Receives segmental innervation from T6–T12.

Transversus abdominis muscle

Does not form the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. Contributes to the roof and posterior wall. Combines with internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon.

Internal oblique muscle (Option B)

Forms parts of the anterior, roof, and posterior walls of the inguinal canal. Contributes to cremasteric muscle and fascia.

External oblique muscle (Option A)

Aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and the superficial inguinal ring. Forms external spermatic fascia.

Internal spermatic fascia

Derived from the transversalis fascia.

Rectus sheath (Option D): The rectus sheath encloses the rectus abdominis muscle and is not involved in the formation of the deep inguinal ring. This is incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

  • Stomach: The correct option is option A. The stomach is located in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen, near the left kidney. It is anatomically adjacent to the left kidney.

Incorrect options: 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is an incorrect option. While the spleen is also located in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen, it is positioned more laterally and superiorly compared to the left kidney.

Option C. 2nd part of duodenum: The second part of the duodenum is an incorrect option. The duodenum is a part of the small intestine, and it is located in the central and upper abdomen. It is positioned more medially and inferiorly compared to the left kidney.

Option D. Pancreas: Option D is not explained in the initial question. However, the pancreas is an incorrect option in relation to the marked area. The pancreas is located behind the stomach and extends horizontally across the abdomen.

questions.text: Testicular artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • Explanation: The testicular artery is a branch of the abdominal aorta.
  • It arises from the anterior aspect of the abdominal aorta just below the origin of the renal arteries.
  • It travels inferiorly to reach the testes and provides the arterial blood supply to the testicles.

Incorrect options :

Option B. Common iliac artery: The common iliac artery is a vessel that arises from the abdominal aorta and bifurcates into the internal and external iliac arteries. It does not directly supply the testicular artery.

Option C. External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is a branch of the common iliac artery and supplies the lower limb. It does not supply the testicular artery.

Option D. Internal iliac artery: The internal iliac artery is a branch of the common iliac artery and supplies the pelvis and pelvic organs. It does not supply the testicular artery.

questions.text: The patient exhibited an enlarged lymph node in the inguinal area. The primary cause that is most probable is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Anal cancer

Explanation:

  • The inguinal lymph nodes primarily drain the lower limb, perineum, external genitalia, and anal canal below the dentate line. Anal cancer (especially if it arises below the pectinate/dentate line) spreads to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making it the most probable cause of an enlarged inguinal lymph node.

 

Lymphatic Drainage of the Rectum and Anal Canal:

Region

Lymphatic Drainage

Upper half of the rectum

Inferior mesenteric nodes via pararectal and sigmoid nodes

Lower half of the rectum & upper anal canal

Internal iliac nodes

Anal canal (below the pectinate line)

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

 

 

 

Testicular cancer (option A): Testes drain to the para-aortic (retroperitoneal) lymph nodes, not the inguinal nodes. Inguinal node involvement is uncommon unless there is scrotal skin involvement.

Sigmoid colon cancer (option C): The sigmoid colon drains to the inferior mesenteric and para-aortic lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.

Prostate cancer (option D): Prostate lymphatic drainage is primarily to the internal iliac and obturator lymph nodes, not the inguinal nodes.

questions.text: Inguinal ligament is formed due to
questions.solution:
Correct option B. 

  • The inguinal ligament is formed due to the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • The external oblique muscle of the abdominal wall gives rise to a broad flat tendon called the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • The lower border of the external oblique aponeurosis forms the inguinal ligament, which extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the pubic tubercle.
  • The inguinal ligament plays a role in supporting the structures of the inguinal region.

Incorrect options :

Option A. Cremaster muscle: The cremaster muscle is a thin muscle that covers the spermatic cord. It is not involved in the formation of the inguinal ligament.

Option C. Internal oblique aponeurosis: The internal oblique muscle contributes to the formation of the conjoint tendon, which is a thickening of the transversalis fascia. It does not directly form the inguinal ligament.

Option D. Transversus abdominis: The transversus abdominis muscle is the deepest muscle of the abdominal wall. It does not contribute to the formation of the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: During embryological development, the midgut undergoes rotation. In a 6-month-old infant presenting with bilious emesis, it is discovered that the cecum is fixed in the right upper quadrant due to peritoneal bands, leading to a diagnosis of intestinal malrotation. Which of the following statements accurately describes the midgut rotation during embryological development?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • During normal embryological development, the midgut rotates 270 degrees anticlockwise (counterclockwise) around the axis of the superior mesenteric artery.
  • This rotation occurs in three stages: 90 degrees during herniation into the umbilical cord, an additional 180 degrees during retraction back into the abdominal cavity.
  • This process positions the cecum in the lower right quadrant of the abdomen and the small intestines in a way that avoids complications such as malrotation.

Incorrect options:

Option A: 270-degree clockwise: This option suggests a clockwise rotation of 270 degrees. However, the midgut rotation occurs in a counterclockwise direction rather than clockwise. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option C: 360-degree clockwise: This option suggests a clockwise rotation of 360 degrees. However, the midgut rotation does not involve a full 360-degree rotation in either direction. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D: 360-degree anticlockwise: This option implies a counterclockwise rotation of 360 degrees. While the counterclockwise rotation is correct, the midgut rotation does not involve a full 360-degree rotation. Hence, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: In relation to the anatomy of vasa brevia, a senior surgeon asks a first-year surgery resident a question that suggests vasa brevia is another term for which artery runs through the gastrosplenic ligament. This scenario is based on a research article published about the branches and course of vasa brevia.
questions.solution:
Correct option: B

  • Short gastric arteries: The short gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus and upper part of the greater curvature of the stomach. They pass through the gastrosplenic ligament, which is a fold of the peritoneum connecting the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Long gastric arteries: The long gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus and upper part of the greater curvature of the stomach. However, they do not pass through the gastrosplenic ligament.

Option C: Ileal vasa recta: The ileal vasa recta are small arteries that arise from the superior mesenteric artery and supply the terminal part of the ileum in the small intestine. They are not associated with the gastrosplenic ligament.

Option D: Jejunal vasa recta: The jejunal vasa recta are small arteries that arise from the superior mesenteric artery and supply the jejunum in the small intestine. Similar to the ileal vasa recta, they are not related to the gastrosplenic ligament.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery originating from celiac trunk territory?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Gastroepiploic artery: The gastroepiploic artery, also known as the gastro-omental artery, is a branch of the celiac trunk territory. It arises from the splenic artery, which is one of the main branches of the celiac trunk. The gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach and supplies blood to the stomach and the greater omentum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Splenic artery: The splenic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk, but it does not originate from the celiac trunk territory. Instead, it arises directly from the celiac trunk itself.

Option C: Gastroduodenal artery: The gastroduodenal artery is another branch of the celiac trunk, but it does not originate from the celiac trunk territory. It arises directly from the common hepatic artery, which is a separate branch of the celiac trunk.

Option D: Left gastric artery: The left gastric artery is also a branch of the celiac trunk, but it does not originate from the celiac trunk territory. It arises directly from the common hepatic artery, just before it gives rise to the proper hepatic artery.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments is another name for the lienorenal ligament derived from the peritoneum, where the tail of the pancreas is located in a healthy adult female?
questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • Spleno-renal: The lienorenal ligament, also known as the splenorenal ligament, is a double-layered fold of peritoneum that connects the spleen to the posterior abdominal wall and the left kidney. It plays a crucial role in supporting and positioning the spleen within the abdominal cavity.

  • Functions:

    • Splenorenal Support: The primary function of the lienorenal ligament is to support the spleen in its anatomical position. The spleen is a relatively mobile organ, and the lienorenal ligament helps anchor it to the posterior abdominal wall and the left kidney, preventing excessive movement and rotation. This support ensures that the spleen remains in its usual location in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.

    • Vascular and Neural Contents: Within the lienorenal ligament, you can find several important structures:

      • Splenic Artery and Vein: The lienorenal ligament contains the splenic artery and vein, which are the main blood vessels supplying and draining the spleen.
      • Lymphatics: Lymphatic vessels from the spleen also pass through the lienorenal ligament.
      • Autonomic Nerves: Nerve fibers related to the autonomic nervous system may also pass through this ligament.

    • Potential Pathway for Disease Spread: Due to its connections with the spleen, stomach, and surrounding structures, the lienorenal ligament can serve as a pathway for the spread of disease or infections between these organs.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Hapato-gastric: The hepatogastric ligament, also known as the lesser omentum, connects the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach

Option B: Hepato-duodenal: The hepatoduodenal ligament, also known as the lesser omentum, connects the liver to the duodenum. Like the hepatogastric ligament, it does not include the tail of the pancreas.

Option C: Gastro-splenic: The gastro-splenic ligament, also known as the lienorenal ligament, is the correct ligament in question. It is derived from the peritoneum and connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The tail of the pancreas lies within this ligament

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud’s classification system is:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

In Couinaud's classification system, the liver is divided into functional units called liver segments. These segments are based on the distribution of the portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile ducts within the liver.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B: The hepatic artery is not the structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system. While the hepatic artery is an important blood vessel that supplies oxygenated blood to the liver, it does not serve as the dividing structure for liver segments.

Option C: The bile ducts, which include the common hepatic duct and its branches, transport bile from the liver to the gallbladder and small intestine. While bile ducts play a significant role in liver function, they are not the dividing structure in Couinaud's classification system.

Option D: The cystic duct is a small duct that connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. It is not involved in the division of the liver according to Couinaud's classification system.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about nerve supply of adrenal gland?

choices.text: Release of catecholamines is not affected by nerve supply to adrenals
Preganglionic fibres from lower thoracic and lumbar vertebra come via sympathetic chain to supply adrenals
Adrenal cortex doesn't have a direct nerve supply
Adrenal medulla doesn’t have nerve supply

questions.solution:
Correct Option : B

  • The preganglionic fibers from the lower thoracic and lumbar segments of the spinal cord come via the sympathetic chain to supply the adrenal medulla.
  • The adrenal gland consists of two main parts: the outer adrenal cortex and the inner adrenal medulla. The adrenal cortex is responsible for the production and secretion of steroid hormones, while the adrenal medulla produces and releases catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine), which are involved in the body's response to stress.
  • The adrenal medulla is innervated by sympathetic preganglionic fibers. These preganglionic fibers arise from the lower thoracic (T10-T12) and lumbar (L1-L2) segments of the spinal cord. They pass through the sympathetic chain ganglia without synapsing and continue as splanchnic nerves to reach the adrenal medulla. Upon reaching the adrenal medulla, these fibers synapse with chromaffin cells, which are specialized cells responsible for the production and release of catecholamines.

Incorrect Option :

Option A . The release of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla is indeed affected by the nerve supply. Stimulation of the sympathetic preganglionic fibers leads to the release of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla into the bloodstream.

Option C. It primarily functions as an endocrine organ, producing hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex hormones. The adrenal medulla, on the other hand, is innervated by sympathetic nerve fibers and plays a role in the release of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine) in response to sympathetic stimulation.

Option D. As mentioned earlier, the adrenal medulla does have nerve supply through the sympathetic preganglionic fibers that synapse with chromaffin cells, leading to the release of catecholamines.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the hepatocystic triangle ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- C) Cystic artery

Explanation

The hepatocystic triangle, also widely known as Calot's triangle or the cystohepatic triangle, is a crucial anatomical landmark for surgeons, especially during gallbladder removal (cholecystectomy).

Its boundaries are generally defined as:

  • Medially: The common hepatic duct (Option B ruled out)
  • Laterally (or Inferiorly): The cystic duct (Option A ruled out)
  • Superiorly: The inferior surface of the liver (Option D ruled out)

Within this triangle, typically find important structures such as:

  • The cystic artery (Option C) (which usually arises from the right hepatic artery)
  • The cystic lymph node (also known as Lund's node)
  • Connective tissue and lymphatics
  • Occasionally, an accessory right hepatic artery or anomalous sectoral bile duct

questions.text: A surgeon by mistake injures one structure posterio to epiploic foramen. Which of the following structure is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inferior vena cava:

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is the IVC (Inferior Vena Cava), as it forms the posterior boundary of the Epiploic Foramen and is therefore the most likely structure to be injured from behind.

Epiploic Foramen / Omental Foramen / Foramen of Winslow

A vertical slit-like opening connecting the lesser sac with the greater sac, located behind the right free margin of the lesser omentum at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra.

Boundaries
  • Anterior: Right free margin of the lesser omentum (portal vein, proper hepatic artery, bile duct)
  • Posterior: Inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, T12 vertebra (Option C)
  • Superior: Caudate process of the liver
  • Inferior: First part of the duodenum, horizontal part of the hepatic artery

Clinical Relevance
  • Pringle Maneuver: A technique to control bleeding from the liver by compressing the free edge of the lesser omentum.
  • Fluid Collections: The apposed walls of the foramen can lead to isolated fluid collections in the greater sac or omental bursa.

 Incorrect Options:

Option A: Abdominal aorta lies posterior to the IVC and is not in direct relation to the epiploic foramen.

Option B: Hepatic artery is part of the anterior boundary within the portal triad.

Option D: Portal vein is part of the anterior boundary within the portal triad, not posterior.

questions.text: Which anatomical plane contains the neurovascular structures supplying the abdominal wall, located below the rectus abdominis muscle and above the transversalis fascia?

choices.text: Between the internal oblique and external oblique
Between the internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis.

Explanation:

  • The neurovascular plane of the anterior abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.
  • This plane contains the intercostal nerves (T7-T11), subcostal nerve (T12), and branches of the lumbar plexus (L1), along with corresponding vessels.

Neurovascular Plane of the Abdominal Wall

Layer of Abdominal Wall

Structures Present

Between skin and external oblique

Superficial fascia, cutaneous nerves.

Between external oblique and internal oblique

No major neurovascular structures.

Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

Neurovascular plane (intercostal nerves, subcostal nerve, lumbar plexus branches, and segmental arteries).

Deep to transversus abdominis

Transversalis fascia, extraperitoneal fat, peritoneum.

Deep to transversus abdominis (Option B): Incorrect because the neurovascular plane is located superficial to transversus abdominis, not deep to it.

Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis (Option C): Incorrect because the rectus abdominis is enclosed by the rectus sheath, and the neurovascular structures run lateral to it, not between it and the internal oblique.

Between internal oblique and external oblique (Option A): Incorrect because this plane does not contain major neurovascular structures.

questions.text: Most common site of Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Posterolateral:

  • The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral region of the diaphragm, specifically the left side. This area is where the foramen of Bochdalek is located, which is a common site for herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central Tendon: Hernias in this area are less common. The central tendon is a structure where the muscle fibers of the diaphragm converge, but it is not typically associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

Option C - Crural: This area refers to the portion of the diaphragm attaching to the lumbar vertebrae. Hernias in this region are not as common as those in the posterolateral area.

Option D - Anterolateral: Hernias in the anterolateral region are rare compared to those in the posterolateral region. This region is less associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

questions.text: A patient presents with fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ileal diverticulum:

  • Ileal diverticulum (Meckel's diverticulum): This is a congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. A vitelline fistula can form, leading to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, which is a characteristic sign.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Urachal fistula: Involves a connection between the bladder and the umbilicus, typically resulting in urine discharge, not fecal material.

Option C - Omphalocele: A congenital defect in the abdominal wall where abdominal contents herniate into the umbilical cord. There is no fecal discharge involved.

Option D - Gastroschisis: A defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, where the intestines protrude without a protective sac. It is not associated with fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

questions.text: What is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Indirect inguinal hernia:

  • Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type of hernia overall, including in females.

  • This type of hernia occurs when abdominal contents protrude through the deep inguinal ring and into the inguinal canal, often due to a congenital defect in the abdominal wall.

  • Despite the anatomical predisposition in females for femoral hernias, indirect inguinal hernias still occur more frequently in both sexes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Obturator hernia:

  • These are quite rare and occur through the obturator foramen. They are typically found in older, multiparous women and are not the most common type of hernia in females.

Option B - Direct inguinal hernia:

  • Direct inguinal hernias occur due to weakness in the abdominal wall in the inguinal (Hesselbach's) triangle. These are more common in men and are not the most common type in females.

Option D - Femoral hernia:

  • While femoral hernias are more common in females compared to males due to the wider female pelvis, they are still less common than indirect inguinal hernias in females.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lienorenal ligament
 

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the Lienorenal ligament or the splenorenal ligament.
  • It connects the spleen to the left kidney as the spleen has come to the left side due to the rotation of the stomach.
  • It also carries the splenic artery.

Omenta:

Sources

Greater omentum

Greater curvature of stomach (and spleen)

Transverse colon

right and left gastroepiploic vessels and fat

The right free margin-hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct,lymph nodes and the lymph vessels,hepatic plexus of nerve,all enclosed in perivascular fibrous sheath. Along the lesser curvature of the stomach-left and right gastric artery,the gastric group of lymph nodes and lymphatics, branches from the gastric nerve.

 

Hepatogastric ligament

questions.text: The fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis contribute to which wall of the inguinal canal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Roof

Explanation:

The roof of the inguinal canal is formed by the fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. These muscles contribute to the structure that covers the canal from above.

The inguinal canal is a passageway in the lower abdominal wall.

Contents of the inguinal canal:

  • In males: Spermatic cord and ilioinguinal nerve
  • In females: Round ligament of the uterus and ilioinguinal nerve

 

The boundaries of the inguinal canal are:

  • Anterior wall: It is formed from superficial to deep by: (Option A)
    • Skin
    • Superficial fascia in its extent.
    • External oblique aponeurosis
    • Internal oblique muscle fibers, in lateral one-third.
  • Posterior wall: It is formed from deep to superficial by: (Option B)
    • Fascia transversalis, in the whole extent
    • Conjoint tendon, in medial two-third
    • Reflected part of the inguinal ligament, in the medial-most part.
  • Roof: It is formed by the lower arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.
  • Floor: It is formed by: (Option D)
    • Grooved upper surface of the inguinal ligament in the whole extent
    • Abdominal surface of the lacunar ligament at the medial end.

                                                             Fig: Contents of Inguinal canal

                                                            Fig: Inguinal canal boundaries

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding the Adrenal gland?

choices.text: The left adrenal gland is present below the spleen
The right adrenal gland is crescent in shape

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The right adrenal gland is crescent in shape

Explanation:

The right adrenal gland is triangular or pyramidal, not crescent-shaped.

Right Adrenal Gland

  • Shape: Pyramidal
  • Parts:
    • Base: Below, overlaps the upper end of the right kidney.
    • Apex: Above, anterior surface presents a hilum.
    • Anterior Surface:
      • Medial area: Related to the inferior vena cava (IVC).
      • Lateral area: Related to the liver.
    • Posterior Surface:
      • Upper area: Related to the diaphragm.
      • Lower area: Related to the kidney.
    • Borders:
      • Lateral: Overlapped by the liver.
      • Medial: Related to:
        • Below: Celiac ganglion.
        • Above: Inferior phrenic artery.

Left Adrenal Gland

  • Shape: Semilunar
  • Parts:
    • Lower End: Rounded, anterior surface presents hilum.
    • Upper End: Narrow, related to the medial end of the spleen (Option B)
    • Anterior Surface:
      • Upper area: Related to the stomach bed.
      • Lower area: Overlapped by the body of the pancreas and crossed by the tortuous splenic artery.
    • Posterior Surface:
      • Lateral area: Related to the left kidney.
      • Medial area: Related to the left crus of the diaphragm.
    • Borders:
      • Lateral: Overlaps the left kidney.
      • Medial: Related to:
        • Below: Celiac ganglion.
        • Above: Inferior phrenic artery.

Yellow-colored structures (Option A): The adrenal cortex tends to exhibit a yellowish hue due to its higher fat content, while the adrenal medulla appears more reddish-brown in color.

It is located retroperitoneally (Option D): The adrenal glands are situated on top of each kidney in the retroperitoneal space.

questions.text: Which of the following drains into the IVC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left renal vein

Explanation:

 

Left Renal Vein directly drains into the Inferior Vena Cava (IVC). This vein receives blood from the left kidney and left gonadal vein.

 

 

Inferior vena cava:

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the right and left common iliac veins at the level of L5 vertebra.
  • Termination: Opens into the lower and posterior part of the right atrium.
  • Course: It ascends along the front of the vertebral column, positioned to the right of the aorta, creates a groove on the posterior surface of the liver, and passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm at the T8 vertebral level.

Tributaries of IVC

Key features

Right and left 3rd and 4th lumbar veins

It drains the posterior, lateral, and anterior abdominal walls into IVC.

Right gonadal vein

Left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right suprarenal vein

Left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.

Right inferior phrenic vein

Left inferior phrenic vein drains into the left suprarenal, or left renal vein.

Right and left renal veins

Left renal vein (7.5cm) is three times longer than right renal vein (2.5cm)

Hepatic veins

Three large and many small veins open directly into the anterior surface of the inferior vena cava just before it pierces the diaphragm.

Left Gonadal Vein (Option A):

The left gonadal vein (left testicular vein in males or left ovarian vein in females) drains into the left renal vein, and then the blood flows into the IVC.

Left adrenal vein (Option B):

The left adrenal vein also drains into the left renal vein, which eventually connects to the IVC.

Right ascending lumbar vein (Option D):

  • Right ascending lumbar vein drain into the azygous vein
  • Azygous vein is on right side
  • Azygous will drain in Superior Vena Cava (SVC) at T4 level

questions.text: All are anterior to the third part of the duodenum except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fundus of gallbladder

Explanation:

  • The third part of the duodenum (horizontal part) lies at the level of L3 and is retroperitoneal. Structures located anterior to it include:
    1. Superior mesenteric artery (SMA)
    2. Superior mesenteric vein
    3. Root of the mesentery
    4. Jejunum
  • The fundus of the gallbladder, however, is located in the right hypochondrium, much higher than the third part of the duodenum, and thus is not anterior to it.

Relations of Duodenum

 

First Part

Second Part

Third Part

Fourth part
    • Anteriorly: Quadrate lobe of liver, gallbladder.
    • Posteriorly: Portal vein, gastroduodenal artery, bile duct.
    • Superiorly: Epiploic foramen.
    • Inferiorly: Head and neck of the pancreas.
    • Anteriorly: Liver, transverse colon, small intestine.
    • Posteriorly: Right kidney, renal vessels, IVC, psoas major.
    • Medially: Head of the pancreas, bile duct.
    • Laterally: Right colic flexure.
    • Anteriorly: Superior mesenteric vessels, the root of the mesentery.
    • Posteriorly: IVC, abdominal aorta, right ureter, gonadal vessels.
    • Superiorly: Head of the pancreas with the uncinate process.
    • Inferiorly: Coils of jejunum.
    • Anteriorly: Transverse colon, transverse mesocolon, stomach.
    • Posteriorly: Left psoas major, left sympathetic chain, left renal artery.
    • Superiorly: Body of pancreas.
    • To the left: Left kidney, left ureter.

questions.text: During the examination of a patient with a hernia, a surgeon forcefully pushes the hernial sac back into the abdominal cavity without directly pushing back the contents first. What type of hernia has occurred as a result of this, which is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reduction en masse

Explanation:

  • Reduction en masse refers to a situation where the hernia sac is forcibly pushed back into the abdominal cavity without properly reducing or returning the herniated contents to their normal position.
  • This can occur when the hernia sac gets stuck or incarcerated within the abdominal wall opening.

Reduction en masse:

  • The condition reduction en masse is a complication associated with an inguinal hernia.
  • In this condition, the herniated sac is inside the abdominal wall but its contents are strangulated.
  • Clinical features:
    • Persistent pain in the lower abdomen
    • Localised or generalised peritonitis
    • Absence of appreciable hernia externally Intestinal obstruction and strangulation

Strangulated Hernia (Option A): This occurs when the blood supply to the herniated contents is cut off, leading to ischemia. It is different from reduction en masse as the hernia contents remain in the hernial sac.

Sliding hernia (Option C):

  • Happens when part of the stomach slides up through the diaphragm opening (hiatus) into the chest cavity, essentially sharing a wall with the hernia sac formed by the diaphragm, causing it to protrude alongside the esophagus
  • This is the most common type of hiatal hernia.

Maydl's hernia (Option D): This is a rare hernia where two loops of bowel are within the hernial sac, with the loop between them (inside the abdomen) being at risk of strangulation.

questions.text: A patient with a medical history of liver cirrhosis now presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension. Anastomosis between which of the following veins will be seen?

choices.text: Left colic vein and middle colic veins
Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

Explanation:

  • The patient has portal hypertension, which is commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.
  • Portal hypertension leads to the development of portosystemic anastomoses, which are connections between the portal vein and systemic venous circulation.
  • One significant site of such an anastomosis is between the esophageal veins (draining into the systemic circulation via the azygos vein) and the left gastric vein (draining into the portal vein).
  • In portal hypertension, increased pressure in the portal vein causes blood to flow through these collateral veins, leading to esophageal varices.

Portal Hypertension:

  • Reversal of blood flow away from the portal vein due to high pressure.

Clinical Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Esophageal varices
  • Rectal varices
  • Caput medusae

Portal-Systemic Anastomoses

Site of anastomosis

Veins forming portocaval anastomosis

Clinical signs

Lower third of the esophagus

Left gastric vein

↑ ↓

Esophageal veins draining into azygos vein

 

Esophageal varices

Umbilicus

Paraumbilical veins

↑↓

Superficial veins of anterior abdominal wall

 

 

Caput medusae

Mid-anal canal

Superior rectal vein

↑↓

Middle and inferior rectal veins

Hemorrhoids

 

Left colic vein and middle colic veins (Option A): These veins are part of the portal circulation and do not form portosystemic anastomoses.

Superior and phrenic veins (Option C): These are systemic veins and do not involve the portal system.

Sigmoid and superior rectal veins (Option D): both are part of the portal circulation but don't drain into the systemic circulation thus anastomoses between them aren't seen in portal hypertension.

questions.text: The para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
• The marked structure in the image is the epiploic foramen (of Winslow), which connects the greater sac and the lesser sac (omental bursa).
  • It is an important anatomical passage located posterior to the free edge of the lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal ligament).
  • The superior border of the epiploic foramen is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver.

Epiploic Foramen and Its Anatomical Borders

Feature

Details

Definition

Communication between greater sac and lesser sac

Superior Border

Caudate lobe of the liver

Anterior Border

Hepatoduodenal ligament (portal triad)

Posterior Border

Inferior vena cava

Inferior Border

First part of duodenum

Clinical Importance

Internal hernias, Pringle maneuver in hepatic trauma

  • Clinical Relevance:
    • The epiploic foramen is significant in internal herniation (e.g., herniation of bowel loops into the lesser sac).
    • Surgical importance: It provides access to the portal triad in the Pringle maneuver, used to control hepatic bleeding.

 

Duodenum (Option B): Incorrect because it forms the inferior border, not the superior.

Lesser omentum (Option C): Incorrect because it forms the anterior border, not the superior.

Inferior vena cava (Option D): Incorrect because it forms the posterior border, not the superior.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the vertical plane that separates the body into anterior and posterior sections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coronal plane

Explanation:

The coronal plane (frontal plane) is the vertical plane that divides the body into anterior (front) and posterior (back) sections. It runs perpendicular to the median plane and is commonly used in imaging and anatomical descriptions.

Anatomical Planes of the Body

Plane

Description

Division

Clinical Relevance

Coronal (Frontal) Plane

Vertical plane passing side to side

Anterior and Posterior

Used in chest X-rays and CT scans

Sagittal (Median) Plane

Vertical plane passing front to back

Left and Right

MRI brain imaging, midline structures

Transverse (Axial) Plane

Horizontal plane

Superior and Inferior

Used in CT and MRI scans

Oblique Plane

Diagonal plane

Varies

Used in specialized imaging

Transverse plane (Option B): incorrect because it divides the body into superior (upper) and inferior (lower) sections.

Axial plane (Option C): incorrect because "axial" is another name for the transverse plane, which divides the body into top and bottom sections.

Median plane (Option D): incorrect because it divides the body into equal left and right halves, not anterior and posterior sections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about thoracolumbar fascia?

choices.text: In the lumbar region, it is in 4 layers
In the thoracic region, it is attached medially to the vertebrae
The anterior, posterior and middle join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) In the lumbar region, it is in 4 layers

Explanation:

  • The thoracolumbar fascia (TLF) is composed of three layers (anterior, middle, and posterior) in the lumbar region, not four. It provides attachment for various muscles and encloses the intrinsic back muscles.

Thoracolumbar Fascia

Region

Layers

Attachments

Function

Thoracic

Single layer

Medially to vertebrae, laterally to ribs

Covers intrinsic back muscles

Lumbar

Three layers (anterior, middle, posterior)

Encloses quadratus lumborum and erector spinae

Supports lumbar spine, transmits forces

 

They contain nociceptive nerve endings (Option A): Correct because thoracolumbar fascia has sensory nerve endings, including nociceptors, which are involved in pain perception.

In the thoracic region, it is attached medially to the vertebrae (Option C): Correct as the fascia in the thoracic region attaches medially to the spinous processes and laterally to the ribs.

The anterior, posterior, and middle join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis (Option D): Correct as the three layers fuse laterally to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis.

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the marked structure correspond?

choices.text: At the junction of L1 & L2
At the junction of L2 & L3
At the junction of T12 & L1
At the junction of L3 & L4

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) At the junction of L3 & L4

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the umbilicus which lies at the junction of L3 & L4. The umbilicus is located at the level of the intervertebral disc between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, the ureters, and the descending colon.

Abdominal planes -

Position of Umbilicus:

  • The position of the umbilicus varies depending on the individual's body shape and size, but it is typically located at the level of the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) or the intervertebral disc between L4 and L5.
  • It is situated in the center of the abdomen, approximately halfway between the xiphoid process at the bottom of the sternum and the pubic symphysis.

 

At the junction of L1 & L2 (Option A): Associated structures at this level include the spinal cord, the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the renal arteries and veins, and the ureters.

At the junction of L2 & L3 (Option B): Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, and the ascending colon.

At the junction of T12 & L1 (Option C): Associated structures at this level include the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the celiac trunk, the superior mesenteric artery, and the renal arteries

questions.text: Please identify the position of the appendix in the image provided.

choices.text: A-Retrocecal; B-Preileal, C- Postileal, D-Pelvic; E- Subcecal
A- Retrocecal; B- Postileal; C Preileal; D-Pelvic: E-Paracecal
A- Retrocecal; B- Postileal; C- Preileal; D - Subcecal; E - Pelvic
A- Retrocecal; B- Postileal; C- Preileal; D-Pelvic; E- Subcecal

questions.solution:
Correct Option is: A- Retrocecal; B- Postileal; C Preileal; D-Pelvic; E Subcecal

Location

Presentation

Retrocecal

May present with flank or back pain

Subcecal

Can mimic gynecological disorders or urinary tract infection

Pre-ileal

May cause small bowel obstruction symptoms

Post-ileal

May cause small bowel obstruction symptoms

Paracecal

Can present with typical right lower quadrant pain

Subhepatic

Can be mistaken for cholecystitis

Pelvic

Can mimic symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease or ovarian pathology

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below?

choices.text:
Internal oblique
B) External oblique
C) Parietal peritoneum
D) Fascia transversalis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fascia transversalis

Explanation:

  • The structure marked in the image corresponds to the deep inguinal ring, a key anatomical feature of the inguinal canal.
  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

 

Structure

Description

Parietal peritoneum

(Option C)

Most posterior structure.

Transversalis fascia

Has a defect called the deep inguinal ring, through which the testes and spermatic cord pass. Site for indirect inguinal hernias. Anterior to parietal peritoneum. Forms the posterior in the whole extent.

Lateral umbilical fold

Formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

Median umbilical ligament

Remnant of the urachus (from the allantois).

Medial umbilical ligament

Remnant of the obliterated umbilical artery.

Pyramidalis muscle

Small muscle attaching to the pubic bone. Rectus abdominis lies above it. Covered by the rectus sheath and supplied by the subcostal nerve (T12).

Rectus abdominis muscle

Receives segmental innervation from T6–T12.

Transversus abdominis muscle

Does not form the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. Contributes to the roof and posterior wall. Combines with internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon.

Internal oblique muscle (Option A)

Forms parts of the anterior, roof, and posterior walls of the inguinal canal. Contributes to cremasteric muscle and fascia.

External oblique muscle (Option B)

Aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and the superficial inguinal ring. Forms external spermatic fascia.

Internal spermatic fascia

Derived from the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following was separated by the cholecysto-vena caval line?

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Right and left lobe of liver: The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn on the visceral surface of the liver. It separates the right lobe of the liver from the left lobe of the liver. The right lobe is larger and encompasses most of the liver's volume, while the left lobe is smaller.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gallbladder and inferior vena cava: The cholecysto-vena caval line doesn't separate the gallbladder and the inferior vena cava. The gallbladder is in the right lobe of the liver, while the inferior vena cava runs alongside the liver.

Option B: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava: The cholecysto-vena caval line doesn't separate the porta hepatis and the inferior vena cava. The porta hepatis is where the hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile ducts connect with the liver.

Option C: Caudate lobe and quadrangular lobe: The cholecysto-vena caval line doesn't divide the caudate lobe and quadrangular lobe. The caudate lobe is posterior on the liver, while the quadrangular lobe is in the left lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Linea semilunaris: The linea semilunaris, also known as the semilunar line, is a curved, fibrous line on the lateral abdominal wall that represents the transition zone between the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle and the rectus sheath.

Incorrect Options :

Option A - Pectineal ligament:

  • The pectineal ligament, or Cooper's ligament, arises from the external oblique's aponeurosis and provides support to the inguinal region.

Option B - Inguinal ligament:

  • The inguinal ligament, also known as Poupart's ligament, is derived from the lower border of the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle.

Option C - Lacunar ligament:

  • The lacunar ligament, known as Gimbernat's ligament, is derived from the lower border of the external oblique muscle's aponeurosis and contributes to the formation of the femoral ring and the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart’s ligament
It inserts into t he pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

  • The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out with the fascia iliaca laterally.
  • The fascia iliaca is a broad, fibrous sheet that covers the iliopsoas muscle and provides attachment for various muscles and structures in the hip and thigh region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia. It is a thickened band of fascia that runs parallel to the inguinal ligament.

Option B - It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract, situated deeper in the anatomical layers, runs parallel to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament) and lies posterior to it.

Option C - It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract does not directly insert into the pubic tubercle. It blends with the transversalis fascia and forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
Correct Option-C: T10: The area marked in the given image corresponds to the T10 dermatome. Each dermatome represents a specific segment of spinal nerve innervation. The T10 dermatome covers the region at the level of the tenth thoracic vertebra, which is consistent with the location shown in the image.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A:T8: The T8 dermatome, positioned slightly higher on the trunk than the marked level in the image, provides sensory innervation to the skin at the eighth thoracic vertebra level.

Option B:T9: The T9 dermatome, situated slightly above the marked level in the image, provides sensory innervation to the skin at the ninth thoracic vertebra level.

Option D: T11: The T11 dermatome, found slightly below the marked level in the image, provides sensory innervation to the skin at the level of the eleventh thoracic vertebra.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundaries of the Calot triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option-D: Gallbladder:

  • The gallbladder is not considered one of the boundaries of the Calot triangle.
  • The Calot triangle is an anatomical space located between the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and cystic artery.
     

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Common hepatic duct: The common hepatic duct is one of the boundaries of the Calot triangle. It carries bile from the liver and joins with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

Option B: Cystic duct: The cystic duct is another boundary of the Calot triangle. It connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and forms the neck of the gallbladder.

Option C: Cystic artery: The cystic artery is also part of the Calot triangle. It arises from the right hepatic artery or its branches and supplies blood to the gallbladder.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labelled 2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Upper border of L3

  • The abdominal plane labeled as 2 is the Subcostal plane, also known as the "plane of the superior mesenteric artery." It's located just below the costal margin, connecting the 10th costal cartilages bilaterally.
  • In the posterior aspect, it corresponds to the upper border of the third lumbar (L3) vertebra. This plane intersects with the aorta, inferior vena cava, and the third part of the duodenum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - lower border of L1

  • At the lower border of L1 is the location of the transpyloric plane, which is also known as the "plane of Addison."

Option B - Upper border of L1

  • The upper border of L1 does not correspond to the subcostal plane.

Option D - Lower border of L4

  •  The lower border of L4 is the location of the intertubercular plane, which is also known as the "plane of the iliac crests.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient underwent an endoscopic examination of the gastrointestinal tract due to recurrent abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. Identify the arrow-marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Brunner's Gland:

  • The given histology slide is of duodenum.
  • Identification points:
    • Wall made up of four layers.
    • Mucosa – presence of numerous broad villi lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli and goblet cells.
    • Presence of crypts of lieberkuhn
    • Presence of submucous Brunner’s gland.
  • The marked structure by the arrow is of Brunner's gland.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the given structure correspond?

choices.text: At the junction of L1 & L2
At the junction of L2 & L3
At the junction of T12 & L1
At the junction of L3 & L4

questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • The marked structure is the umbilicus which lies at the junction of L3 & L4. The umbilicus is located at the level of the intervertebral disc between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, the ureters, and the descending colon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - At the junction of L1 & L2:  Associated structures at this level include the spinal cord, the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the renal arteries and veins, and the ureters.

Option B - At the junction of L2 & L3:  Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, and the ascending colon. 

Option C - At the junction of T12 & L1:  Associated structures at this level include the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the celiac trunk, the superior mesenteric artery, and the renal arteries.

questions.text: A condition requires the surgery depicted in the image shown below. All the following are usually seen associated with this condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Absent kidney:

  • Although renal anomalies can occur in Heterotaxy polysplenia syndrome, the absence of a kidney (unilateral renal agenesis) is not typically associated with this condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hepatic artery anomalies: Anomalies or variations in the hepatic artery can be seen in Heterotaxy polysplenia syndrome, as the condition affects the normal development and arrangement of abdominal organs.

Option C - Malrotation of the gut: Malrotation of the gut, where the intestines are not properly positioned during development, is a common finding in Heterotaxy polysplenia syndrome.

Option D - Polysplenia: Polysplenia is commonly associated with the condition depicted in the image.

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphaloceles?

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Physiological hernia failing to go back:

Omphalocele is believed to result from a physiological herniation of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord during early fetal development. Normally, the abdominal contents herniate into the umbilical cord at around 6 weeks of gestation but then return back into the abdominal cavity. However, in the case of omphalocele, this physiological herniation fails to go back, resulting in the persistence of the herniated organs outside the abdominal cavity.

Incorrect Options :

Option A) Excessive length of the intestine:

Omphalocele occurs due to a defect in abdominal muscle development, leading to organ herniation through the umbilical ring, not because of excessive intestinal length..

Option C) Herniation of liver:

Omphalocele involves abdominal organs, like the liver, herniating through the umbilical ring. However, it's not only about liver herniation; other abdominal organs are also involved.

Option D) Herniation of umbilicus:

Omphalocele does not involve the herniation of the umbilicus itself but rather the herniation of abdominal organs through the umbilical ring.

questions.text: At which vertebral level can the celiac vessel be observed in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:T12

The celiac trunk emerges from the abdominal aorta just below the diaphragm's aortic opening, around the T12-L1 intervertebral disc level. It courses forward to the right and divides into three branches.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Coeliac vessel does not arise from T9 vertebral level.

Option B. Coeliac vessel does not arise from T10 vertebral level.

Option D. Coeliac vessel does not arise from L2 vertebral level.
